text: - [Gy Panday] Leading industry reports

suggest that 60 to 80%
of world's data is cold.
Just about every business can benefit
from having an archive strategy
that maximizes the value of cold data.

Modern data archiving is not
only about lowering costs

for cold data, but is also
about setting up mechanisms

so that when you need
to put the data to work,
you can access it as quickly
as your business requirements demand.

Hi, I'm Gy Panday, a product
manager for Amazon S3 Glacier,

and I'm excited to show you
how you can use S3 Glacier

to improve your data
restore time by up to 85%,

enabling you to process
restore data faster.

Diana Yeung, a software
engineer for S3 Glacier,

will also be joining us
in a few minutes to demo
how you can take advantage

of this new S3 Glacier
performance improvement.
But before we dive deeper into restores,
I want to give you a quick overview
of Amazon S3 Glacier storage classes.

Amazon S3 Glacier is a
leader in cloud cold storage

and was the first to
offer a branded solution
in this space over 10 years ago.

Amazon S3 has three purpose-built
archive storage classes
for rarely-accessed data.

These storage classes range
from milliseconds retrieval
with S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval,
retrieval in minutes to hours
with S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval,
and retrievals in 12 to 48 hours
with S3 Glacier Deep Archive.
In this short video, we will focus

on the S3 Glacier Flexible
Retrieval storage class
and its standard retrieval tier.
Although S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval

and S3 Glacier Deep Archive
require a restore request

before data can be accessed,
our customers tell us
that they still want high throughput

in case the need to access
large portions of the data.

This is why in November
2022, we increased the rate

at which S3 Glacier
accepts restore requests,

effectively increasing the
potential restore throughput

for millions to billions
of objects by 10 times.

In 2022, customers restored
over two billion objects

in just one week and we've
seen even bigger workloads
this year as customers take advantage
of the additional restore throughput.

With more and more
customers around the world
deriving business value from cold data,

we saw a need to give
customers the ability
to not only get higher throughput
but also get restores starting faster.

That's why we are improving
S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval
data restore time by up to 85%.

This performance improvement
is available to you
at no additional cost.
Faster data restores automatically apply
to the standard retrieval tier
when using Amazon S3 Batch Operations.

Restores from S3 Glacial
Flexible Retrieval

now begin to return
objects within minutes,

enabling you to process
restore data faster.
With this performance improvement,

you can begin processing your
machine learning analytics,
media, and backup data within minutes
of initiating restores.
Now I'm gonna pass it over to Diana
to walk you through a quick demo.
- [Diana Yeung] Hi, everyone.

As Gy mentioned earlier,
my name is Diana Yeung

and I'm a senior software
engineer for Amazon S3 Glacier.

I've seen firsthand
just how important it is

for our customers to have fast
access to their archive data,

which is why I'm so excited
to be here with you today

discussing the improvement in
S3 Glacier data restore time.

I'm going to walk you
through how you can use

S3 Batch Operations to
initiate standard restores.
We will initiate restores
for 250 objects of 100 megabyte each,
totaling 25 gigabyte that are stored
in S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval.
Before the demo, I wanna illustrate

just how powerful the
new improvements are.
As you can see from the blue line,

the previous restore
performance for objects
in Glacier Flexible Retrieval
initiated via the standard retrieval tier,

typically finished within
three to five hours.
With the improvements we have made,

the same restores will
now start within minutes.
Let's show you how.

Before you start using
S3 Batch Operations,
S3 must have permissions to perform
S3 Batch Operations on your behalf.

Grant these permissions
through an AWS Identity

and Access Management role,
also known as an IAM role.

I've already applied the
permissions for this demo.

I've also configured
S3 event notifications
to report when restores start and finish.
Now let's go ahead with the demo.
You can access Batch Operations
on the Amazon S3 console homepage.

Once here, we can start
configuring our job
by clicking on create job.
On the next page, select the AWS region
in which your bucket is located.

Next, you specify the manifest
that lists all the objects

you want to restore, which
can be a list created

through an inventory report
or your own list of objects.
For this demo, I have prepared a CSV file
that lists objects we want to restore.

This file lists the bucket
name in the first columns
and the object keys in the second column.
We will click next to the next page.

On this page, you will
choose the operation type,
which in this case is restore.

Once selected, a new set
of options appear below.
Since the objects we want to restore
are S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval,

we will select the first
option under restore source
that says Glacier Flexible Retrieval
or Glacier Deep Archive.
With this relatively small restore,

we should easily be
able to do what we need
with the restore objects within one day,
so I'm going to select one day retention.

If your data was in the
S3 Intelligent Tiering
Archive Access Tier,

you could still benefit
from faster restores,
but the console won't ask you to specify

the number of days to
store the restored copy
because your objects will be moved

to the S3 Intelligent
Tiering Frequent Access Tier.
Finally, since faster restores
through S3 Batch Operations are available
on the standard retrieval tier,
we will select that option and click next.

On the final page, we will
configure two more options.
First, we select the destination
to write the completion report.

Then we choose the IAM role
that gives S3 Batch Operations
the permission to perform this operation.

When we click next, it
takes us to the review page.

We review details, and once
everything looks correct,
we will click create job at the bottom.

Now our S3 Batch Operations
restore job will be created.
Let's wait for the job to be ready.

I will refresh the page and
it looks like it is now ready.

Let's select the job and
click run job at the top.
Let's review the details one more time,
and once everything is correct,

you can confirm by clicking
run job at the bottom.

We'll come back shortly
when the job finishes.
The job just finished.
You can see here that all the objects
we initiated at time 7:14.
The first object was restored 22 minutes
after we initiated the restore,

and the last object was
restored after 26 minutes.

So in summary, we restored 250
objects totaling 25 gigabyte

in 26 minutes from S3
Glacier Flexible Retrieval.

I'm really excited for you to
start using this new feature

and I look forward to
hearing about even more ways

you are reinventing your
business with archive data.
Back to you, Gy.
- [Gy Panday] Thank you, Diana.
You just saw an example of a workload
that can finish in under an hour.
Now I want to discuss how you can benefit
from faster retrievals with larger jobs.
Let's walk through an example.
Say you need to generate thumbnails

of images stored in S3
Glacier Flexible Retrieval.
You have 10 million of these images,
totaling around 95 terabytes.

In the first step, you
specify all your objects

in an S3 Batch Operations job
and initiate your restore job
using the standard retrieval tier.

Your restores automatically
start within minutes.
Now you could invoke AWS Lambda functions

across all your objects after
all the restores complete,
but because restores are starting sooner,
you can use that to your advantage
to complete the overall workflow faster
so you can configure Lambda to run
based on restore event notifications,

which can run Lambda function
to create a thumbnail

as soon as each object
completes restoring.
This processes the data in parallel
to your completing restore job.

For large workloads, this can
significantly reduce the time
it takes to process data end to end.
Now, let's summarize the benefits

of this S3 Glacier
performance improvement.
Faster restore speeds on the standard tier

are now available using
S3 Batch Operations.
Even your large workloads can now benefit
from higher throughput available
from restores starting in minutes.

Many customers tell us that
they're keeping the data

because they recognize
its future potential.

To learn even more about how
you can maximize the value

of your cold storage
with Amazon S3 Glacier,
scan the QR code to access our new ebook.

This ebook will tell
you why and show you how

Amazon S3 Glacier is helping
organizations of all sizes

and from all industries
transform their data archiving

to unlock business
value, increase agility,
and save on storage costs.
Maximizing the value of archived assets

to reinvent your business and
accelerate your innovation,

that is the real value that
Amazon SG Glacier delivers.

We are excited to see how
you use faster data restores

with S3 Glacier to further
modernize your data archive.
Thank you for your time.
